title: Live: A386 completely closed due to ice on road
text:
The Met Office has issued a weather warning devonlive Bookmark
Share
By Molly Seaman Updated 07:25, 3 JAN 2025 Bookmark
Devon A-road completely closed due to ice (Image: Getty Images) A busy A-road in Devon is partially blocked this morning, Friday, January 3, due to bad driving conditions. The A386 between Bideford and Taddiport is affected in both directions due to ice on the road.
Roads an traffic monitoring site Inrix initially reported the road as completely closed at 1.08am. It said: "A386 in both directions closed due to ice from Devonshire Park (Bideford) to Rakeham Hill (Taddiport)." It later reported that it was partially closed.
The Met Office has a weather warning in place for snow and ice which covers parts of Devon. The warning, in place from 12pm tomorrow (January 4) until 11.59pm on Sunday (January 5), warns that heavy snow and some freezing rain may cause disruption.
This is a live blog. Please scroll down for the latest updates.

Share 06:37 Molly Seaman UKHSA Cold Health Alert The UKHSA has issued an amber cold-health alert until January 8. The forecast weather is expected to cause significant impacts across health and social care services. The UKHSA said:
a rise in deaths, particularly among those aged 65 and over or with health conditions. We may also see impacts on younger age groups a likely increase in demand for health services temperatures inside places like hospitals, care homes, and clinics dropping below the levels recommended for assessing health risks challenges keeping indoor temperatures at the recommended 18°C leading to more risk to vulnerable people staffing issues due to external factors (such as travel delays) other sectors starting to observe impacts (such as transport and energy) Share 06:29 Molly Seaman Snow and ice weather warning A yellow weather warning for snow and ice (Image: Met Office ) Share 06:23 Molly Seaman How to drive safely during icy conditions It is safer to avoid driving during icy conditions, but if you must there are a number of things you can to to keep yourself and other safe. The Met Office advises:
Look ahead for potential hazards Keep your speed down Accelerate, brake, steer and change gear as smoothly as possible to reduce the risk of a skid Use a high gear to help grip on packed ice and find traction Share 06:21 Molly Seaman Met Office weather warning What should I expect?
There is a small chance that power cuts will occur and other services, such as mobile phone coverage, may be affected There is a slight chance that some rural communities could become cut off A small chance of injuries from slips and falls on icy surfaces There is a chance of travel delays on roads with some stranded vehicles and passengers, along with delayed or cancelled rail and air travel
